sections.name: Decision Making
sections.description: Looks at your ability to apply logic to reach a decision or conclusion, evaluate arguments and analyse statistical information.

stems.text: A critique gives a star rating to each restaurant that he visits. Restaurants are rated between 1 and 5 stars (with 5 being the highest and 1 being the lowest). If a restaurant is rated above 3 stars, a bonus is paid out to the restaurant manager. If a restaurant is rated below 2 stars, it is shut down. If a restaurant is rated 5 stars, its picture is included in the local newspaper alongside other reputable restaurants

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If a restaurant is rated 4, a bonus will be paid out to the manager
All restaurants are rated between 1 and 5 stars
If a restaurant is shut down, it must have received a rating of below 2 stars
If a restaurant’s picture is in the newspaper, it must have received 5 stars
A restaurant that is rated 5 stars will have its picture included in the local newspaper and a bonus is paid out to its manager
questions.explanation: If a restaurant is rated above 3 stars, a bonus is paid out to the restaurant manager. Some restaurants may not be rated by this critique. A restaurant may have been shut down for other reasons. A restaurant may have been included in the newspaper for other reasons. If a restaurant is rated 5 stars, its picture is included in the local newspaper alongside other reputable restaurants

stems.text: At a takeaway restaurant, customers are given the option to buy chips, pizza, hamburgers and/or nuggets. Pizza is twice as expensive as chips.  A customer who has $9 can either buy a hamburger or pizza and chips with no change provided. Nuggets are the cheapest item on the menu.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Pizza is the most expensive item on the menu
A customer can buy one of each menu item for $20
Nuggets cannot cost $3.50
Hamburgers sold at this restaurant are very expensive
The minimum amount (to the nearest dollar) that a customer should bring to pay for nuggets (ensuring they are not short on money) is $3
questions.explanation: Hamburgers are the most expensive item. Pizza, chips and a hamburger will cost $9 + $6 + $3 = $18 but nuggets may cost between $2 and $3. Nuggets are less than $3 (chips). While they are the most expensive item we cannot say whether the hamburgers sold at this restaurant are expensive relatively. Nuggets cannot cost $3 or more

stems.text: All members of a family, except for Jim, likes Indian food. More than 2 members of the family also like Italian food.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Jim does not like Italian food
There could be 3 members in Jim’s family
There are least 4 members in Jim’s family
Jim might not like Indian food or Italian food
If there are 5 members in Jim’s family, more than half of his family likes both Italian and Indian food
questions.explanation: Jim might like Italian food. At least 3 members like Indian and Italian food and Jim does not like Indian food, hence there could not be 3 members in Jim’s family. There are least 4 members in Jim’s family for that reason. Jim might not like Italian food either. If there are 5 members in Jim’s family, 3 members only (including Jim) could like Italian food – meaning only 2 members like both Italian and Indian food

stems.text: All those at an interschool meet are students of 3 schools - A, B and C.  Students from all those 3 schools are at the meet. All students of school A study chemistry. Only 50% of students of school B study English. No students of school C study Biology.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Some students who study chemistry will be at the meet
Some students who study English will be at the meet
No students who study biology will be at the meet
If a student studying chemistry is at the meet, s/he must be from school A
If a student studying biology is at the meet, s/he must be from school A or B
questions.explanation: Some students from school A will be at the meet and all students of school A study chemistry. There may not be any English students (from school B) or other schools at the meet. There may be students who study biology at the meet (just not from school C). If a student studying chemistry is at the meet, s/he may be from school A. If a student studying biology is at the meet, s/he cannot be from school C and hence must be from school A or B

stems.text: 5 different-coloured blocks are stacked vertically on top of each other. The blocks are coloured red, green, yellow, blue or orange.  The orange block is between the red and yellow blocks (not necessarily adjacent however).  The green block is above the yellow block but below the red block (not necessarily adjacent however). The blue block is directly above (adjacent to) the green block. The orange block is closer to the top of the stack than the bottom.

questions.text: Which coloured block is in the middle of the stack?
options: Blue
Green
Red
Yellow
questions.explanation: Top to bottom: Red, Orange, blue, green, yellow

stems.text: Samantha was Jim and Jill’s first daughter. In 2003, Jill and Jim (who just turned 35) adopted Maryanne. By 2008, Maryanne was half of Samantha’s age. In 2018, Samantha married Bill, who was 29 years old and, thus, 3 years older than Samantha

questions.text: How much older than Maryanne was Jill when she adopted Maryanne?
questions.explanation: Samantha was born in 2018 – 26= 1992; 2008 – Samantha was 16 and Maryanne 8. Maryanne was born in 2000 and was 3 when adopted. 35 – 3 =32

stems.text: Timothy is at a candy shop that sells gummy worms, yogurt strips, gobstoppers, gum and lollipops. They cost $0.30, $0.40, $0.70, $1.10, $1.30 per piece in no particular order. He has a $5 allowance to spend at the shop. He can buy 3 lollipops and 1 gobstopper without receiving any change. Or, he can buy 10 pieces of gum and 5 gummy bears without receiving any change. Timothy chooses to buy 2 lollipops, 1 gobstopper, 1 yogurt strip and X pieces of gum.

questions.text: Given that he doesn’t receive any change, what is the value of X?
questions.explanation: Lollipop = $1.30 and gobstopper = $1.10; gum = $0.30 and gummy bears = $0.40; yogurt strip = $0.70; $2.60 + $1.10 + $0.70 = $4.40; therefore 2 pieces of gum can be bought

stems.text: Chuck caught 30 bugs from his garden and put them in a glass bowl. The bugs he caught were spiders, ants and beetles. Beetles and ants have 6 legs while spiders have 8 legs. He caught thrice as many ants as beetles. In total, there were 200 legs in the glass bowl.

questions.text: How many more ants than spiders did Chuck catch?
questions.explanation:
Let b = beetles, s = spiders
4b + s = 30
24b + 8s = 200
b = 5, s = 10

stems.text: Flynn surveyed 54 of his friends about their favourite leisure activity. All 54 friends chose one of five leisure activities (sport, flying kites, board games, fishing & camping). 4 more friends chose fishing than camping. Twice as many friends chose sport than flying kites. 4 more friends chose flying kites than fishing. Board games were equally popular as flying kites.

questions.text: How many friends chose board games as their favourite leisure activity?
questions.explanation: Fishing = Camping + 4, sport = 2 x kites, Kites = fishing +4, Kites – 4 = Camping + 4, Camping = kites - 8. Let kites = x: x + x – 4 + 2x + x = 8 + x = 54; 6x = 66, x = 11

stems.text: 4 cars were parked in front of a shop, in parking bays 1,2, 3, 4. The cars included a convertible, hatch, 4WD and sedan. The cars were painted different colours - blue, white, black and red. The 4WD was not red. The red car was parked next to the sedan. The hatch and convertible each only had one neighbouring car. The car parked in bay 3 was black and not the 4WD.

questions.text: Which of the following can be known for certain?
options: The 4WD was blue
The hatch was red
The convertible was red
The sedan was black
questions.explanation: 1: Hatch/convertible, 2: 4WD, 3: black sedan, 4: red hatch/convertible

questions.text: To improve the health outcomes of the impoverished, should medical drugs be subsidised for only the poorer members of the community?
options: Yes; as prescribed drugs (such as antibiotics for bacterial infection) are essential in treating illnesses and, thus, could improve the health outcomes of the impoverished

Yes; as only a portion of the population will be eligible for the subsidies, this may allow a greater degree of subsidisation of drugs for the impoverished; thus, reducing the prices of necessary medical drugs and improving access to these drugs amongst poorer members of community (who may otherwise suffer from preventable illnesses)
No; as such a move will introduce the potential for discrimination based on socioeconomic status and, thus, throw the healthcare system into disarray
No; as other members of society (who are not necessarily impoverished) may not have the ability to buy necessary medical drugs
questions.answer: Yes; as only a portion of the population will be eligible for the subsidies, this may allow a greater degree of subsidisation of drugs for the impoverished; thus, reducing the prices of necessary medical drugs and improving access to these drugs amongst poorer members of community (who may otherwise suffer from preventable illnesses)
questions.explanation: Option B is specific to health outcomes of the impoverish (unlike C and D) and thoroughly explains the reasons behind this improved access to drugs

questions.text: Should cloning be legalised within Australia?
options: Yes; certain types of cloning should be legalised. For example, organ cloning has the capacity to increase the longevity and quality of life for individuals with a variety of illnesses and cloning can lead to new, unanticipated genetic discoveries
Yes; as cloning has the potential to allow infertile parents have children from cloned cells
No; as cloning technology has not been perfected yet, the ramifications of legalised cloning will be disastrous for Australian society
No; as there are too many unresolved ethical and legal implications of full organism cloning
questions.answer: Yes; certain types of cloning should be legalised. For example, organ cloning has the capacity to increase the longevity and quality of life for individuals with a variety of illnesses and cloning can lead to new, unanticipated genetic discoveries
questions.explanation: Option A is the strongest argument as it takes a nuanced stance on the issue and thoroughly explains the stance (unlike the other arguments)

questions.text: For the sake of students, should standardised testing be abolished?
options: Yes; as standardised testing can put excessive pressure on students and have detrimental impacts on their mental state
Yes; as standardised testing provides only a snapshot (rather than a holistic picture) of a student’s ability
No; as standardised testing is an important metric for learning and important in pinpointing areas for improvement for students

No; while standardised testing may subject students to stress/ anxiety in the short term, it can provide them with valuable lessons in the long term (such as the importance of hard work and concentration)
questions.answer: No; while standardised testing may subject students to stress/ anxiety in the short term, it can provide them with valuable lessons in the long term (such as the importance of hard work and concentration)
questions.explanation: Option D is the strongest argument as it takes a nuanced stance on the issue – acknowledging the opposing view but reinforcing the value of testing in the long term

questions.text: To meet the current energy demands of society, should alternative energy be used instead of fossil fuels?
options: Yes; as fossil fuels are a non-renewable, unsustainable source of energy that cannot be replenished at the rate it is being consumed
Yes; as alternative energy is more carbon neutral than fossil fuels, is less environmentally degradational and is less likely to contribute to global warming
No; fossil fuels are much cheaper and more convenient to use than alternative energy

No; while not as sustainable as alternative energy, current technology is well-developed to harness energy from fossil fuels and more research into alternative energy is required before a complete transition can be made
questions.answer: No; while not as sustainable as alternative energy, current technology is well-developed to harness energy from fossil fuels and more research into alternative energy is required before a complete transition can be made
questions.explanation: The prompt asks about current energy demands (not future demands) and D best addresses this by evaluating the current technology

stems.text: Number of shoes sold (and proportion of Nike shoes of the shoes sold) in the last 7 months of 2018; source: https://blog.hubspot.com/marketing/add-secondary-axis-chart-excel

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Nike sales increased over the course of the year
When the number of shoe sales increased, the number of Nike shoes sold decreased
When the number of shoe sales decreased, the number of Nike shoes sold increased
There is an inverse relationship between the number of shoes sold and the percent of Nike shoes sold
The percentage of Nike shoes sold did not rise above 90% in the second half of 2018
questions.explanation: Nike sales largely decreased over the last 7 months of the year. When the number of shoe sales increased, the number of Nike shoes sold largely increased. When the number of shoe sales decreased, the number of Nike shoes sold largely decreased. The percent of Nike shoes sold decreased as the number of shoes sold increased and vice versa. The percentage of Nike shoes sold did not rise above 84% in the second half of 2018

stems.text: Enzymes are catalysts that, within the mild conditions of temperature, pH, and pressure of the cells, carry out chemical reactions at amazingly high rates. Enzymes can be named by adding the suffix -ase to the name of the substrate that they modify (i.e., urease and tyrosinase), or the type of reaction they catalyse (dehydrogenase, decarboxylase). Some have arbitrary names (e.g trypsin). The International Union of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology assigns each enzyme a name and a number to identify them. Enzymes are classified into six categories according to the type of reaction catalysed: Oxidoreductases, transferases, hydrolases, lyases, ligases, and isomerases. Structurally, the vast majority of enzymes are proteins.Also RNA molecules have catalytic activity(ribozymes).Coenzymes are small nonprotein molecules that are associated to some enzymes.Many coenzymes are related to vitamins.Coenzymes and the protein portion with catalytic activity or apoenzyme form the holoenzyme. Source: https: //www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/enzymes

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Amylase catalyses the breakdown of Amyl
Tyrosinase modifies Tyrosin
Enzymes are categorised based on the substate they modify
Ribozymes are made of RNA
Pepsin (a protein) cannot be a coenzyme
questions.explanation: We cannot assume this as some have arbitrary names. The text specifically suggests that tyrosinase is named by adding the suffix -ase to the name of the substrate. Enzymes are classified into six categories according to the type of reaction catalysed. RNA molecules have catalytic activity (ribozymes); hence, Ribozymes are made of RNA. Coenzymes are small nonprotein molecules

stems.text: The terms 'gene technology', 'genetic engineering' and 'genetic manipulation', 'genetic enhancement', 'gene splicing', 'transgenics' or the use of 'recombinant DNA' are terms used to describe genetic modification processes. They all refer to one application of biotechnology. Genes can be found in and moved between different plants, animals or micro-organisms such as viruses or bacteria. Genes can also be altered within a specific plant, animal or micro-organism. For example, an undesirable characteristic such as susceptibility to a particular disease can be 'switched off' or modified in some way to benefit the plant or animal. It is this application of biotechnology that is regulated under the Gene Technology Regulatory Scheme, in recognition of the need to advance with caution with this powerful technology. Source: http://agriculture.vic.gov.au/agriculture/innovation-and-research/biotechnology/what-is-biotechnology

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Gene splicing relates to genetic modification
Genes are rarely found in micro-organisms
Genes can be suppressed via alteration
Genes are often modified to benefit viruses or bacteria
The text recognises the importance of unreserved optimism when discussing gene technology
questions.explanation: Gene splicing is used to describe a genetic modification process. Genes can be found in and moved between different micro-organisms such as viruses or bacteria. An undesirable characteristic such as susceptibility to a particular disease can be 'switched off'. We can’t tell whether genes are often modified to benefit viruses or bacteria. The text acknowledges the need to advance with caution with this powerful technology

stems.text: Growing advances in technology with each coming year has affected humanity in many ways. One of these has been the ability to save lives and create better medical treatment for all. A direct result of this has been increased lifespan and the growth of the population. In the past fifty or so years, the growth of population has boomed and has turned into overpopulation. In the history of our species, the birth and death rate have always been able to balance each other and maintain a population growth rate that is sustainable. Since the time of the Bubonic Plague in the 1400’s, the growth of population has been on a constant increase. Between the time of the plague and the 21st century, there was been hundreds and thousands of wars, natural calamities and man-made hazards. However, none of these have made a dent on the population. Developing nations face the problem of overpopulation more than developed countries, but it affects most of the Earth as of now. Source: https://www.conserve-energy-future.com/causes-effects-solutions-of-overpopulation.php

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Technology can positively impact health outcomes
Overpopulation has been an issue since the 1400s
Population growth cannot occur if birth rates and death rates balance each other
The Bubonic Plague did not make a dent in the population
The death rate is lower in developing nations than developed nations
questions.explanation: Technology has the ability to save lives and create better medical treatment for all. In the past fifty or so years, the growth of population has boomed and has turned into overpopulation. Even if the birth and death rate balance each other, a population can maintain a growth rate that is sustainable. We can’t tell the effect of the Bubonic plague exactly but it likely stunted population growth. Developing nations face the problem of overpopulation more than developed countries but this isn’t to say that the death rate is lower

stems.text: https://physicsforfreshmen.weebly.com/how-to-create-data-tables-and-scientific-graphs.html

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The subjects may have varied in their natural pupil diameter
Pupil diameter increases in accordance with darkness
The brightness was adjusted in trials 1, 2 and 3
Subject 5 had the largest average pupil diameter in light and dark
More subjects are required to determine a definitive trend between brightness and pupil diameter
questions.explanation: The pupil diameter initially varied between subjects. Pupil diameter was largest in dark conditions. We do not know whether the brightness was adjusted in trials 1, 2 and 3. Subject 5 had the largest average pupil diameter in light and dark. A trend was shown between brightness and pupil diameter – even with only 6 subjects

stems.text:
The jobs of those attending a council meeting were recorded and displayed in the following Venn diagram.
Square= Cleaner.
Arrow= Teacher.
Triangle= Shop assistant.
Circle= Tutor

questions.text: Which of the following can be deduced from the Venn diagram?
options: None of those in attendance work 3 jobs
Some tutors in attendance were cleaners
Some teachers in attendance were also tutors
No tutors in attendance were shop assistants
questions.answer: Some teachers in attendance were also tutors
questions.explanation: An overlap between the arrow (teachers) and circle (tutors) can be seen

stems.text:
To determine whether her employees were getting an adequate breakfast, the manager of a company surveyed all her employees. She asked them what they eat/ drink (coffee or tea) for breakfast. The results are represented in the following diagram.
Rectangle= Tea
Triangle= Coffee
Rhombus= Fruit
Circle= Toast
Pentagon= Baked beans

questions.text: Which of the following is true?
options: More employees have toast alone than tea alone
21 employees only have a drink for breakfast
More employees don’t have a drink than have a drink for breakfast
Fruit is more popular than toast amongst employees for breakfast
questions.answer: 21 employees only have a drink for breakfast
questions.explanation: The number of employees that only have tea or coffee is 12 + 9 = 21

stems.text: A school offers the opportunity for students to learn 2 musical instruments – the guitar and the piano. Students can learn one, both or neither instruments. The probability that a randomly selected student learns the guitar is 0.56. The probability that a randomly selected student learns the piano is 0.67. The probability that a randomly selected student learns both the piano and guitar is 0.38.

questions.text: If there are 200 students in the school, how many play neither the piano nor the guitar?

stems.text: A school offers a core subject (which most students study) in addition to a number of elective subjects.Students can study 2 electives at most. Christina (represented by letter A) studies English, maths and science. Helena (represented by letter B) studies maths and science. Radwina (represented by letter C) studies maths, English and history.

questions.text: What subjects do the student represented by letter E study?
options: English and science
English and maths
Maths and science
Maths and history
questions.explanation: E is an overlap between the circle (science) and the star (English)

stems.text: Marissa rolls a biased dice 22 times. The probability that the dice lands on 6 is q. She lands on 6 22 times.

questions.text: The probability she lands on 6 on the next roll is 1.
options: Yes; as q must equal 1
No; the probability is less than q as she is bound to roll a number other than 6 soon
No; the probability is q
questions.explanation: While she has landed on 6 22 times, this doesn’t mean that she will on the next roll. The probability still remains q

stems.text: Bill (a researcher) went to a school in Western Australia. He spoke to 30 random students and 10 of them said that they were interested in studying medicine. Using this data, Bill wrote a report stating that 1/3 of students in Western Australia are interested in studying medicine.

questions.text: Is Bill correct?
options: Yes; as he took a fair random sample
No; as he is generalising from a (albeit fair) sample
No; as the sample is not necessarily representative of the general population
questions.answer: No; as the sample is not necessarily representative of the general population
questions.explanation: All the sample were from a single school and, hence, not representative of the brooder population

stems.text: 4 janitors clean a corporate building. This corporate building is open all 30 days of September. Each janitor takes 3 days off in the month of September but at least 3 janitors are cleaning the corporate building every day of September.

questions.text: If the manager of the company walks in on a random day in September, what is the probability that he will see all 4 janitors cleaning?
questions.explanation: A janitor has a day off on 4 x 3 = 12 days; (30 – 12)/30 = 0.6

stems.text: Tabetha has a box of identical white shoes. In the box, there are 4 individual shoes (for the left foot) and 4 individual shoes (for the right foot). Tabetha has to randomly draw individual shoes from the box to ensure that she has at least 2 pairs (right and left) of shoes.

questions.text: What is the minimum number of shoes that she must draw from the box to be certain that she has 2 pairs of shoes?
questions.explanation: She needs to consider pulling out 4 left socks and only 2 right socks or 4 rights socks and only 2 left socks. In either scenario, the minimum is 6

stems.text: A lady has just had genetically identical triplets. Generally, children have an equal chance of being a boy or girl. The first child is a boy.

questions.text: The probability that the lady has at least one girl is 3/4
options: Yes; as she is highly unlikely to have all 3 boys
No; the probability is 1/2
No; the probability is 0
questions.explanation: The children are genetically identical and thus will all be boys

stems.text: A shop is selling two phone provider plans (plan X and plan Y) – one of which Jaymi will buy. Dropouts refer to an interruption of phone signal and are undesirable. Plan X has a signal dropout rate of 4 out of every 100 calls. Plan X costs $20 fortnightly. Plan Y has a signal dropout rate of 2.5%. Plan Y costs $40 monthly.

questions.text: Based on only price of the plans and their dropout rates, should Jaymi buy plan Y?
options: Yes; as plan Y has a lower signal dropout rate
Yes; as plan Y is cheaper yearly
No; as plan X has a higher signal dropout rate
No; as both plan X and Y have the same cost and signal dropout rate
questions.answer: Yes; as plan Y has a lower signal dropout rate
questions.explanation: While both cost $40 monthly, plan Y has a lower dropout rate of 2.5% - compared to 4% with plan X
